lines.text: A woman's beautiful only when she is loved.
A woman is beautiful when she's loved, and only then.
Nonsense. A woman is beautiful when she has eight hours' sleep and goes to the beauty parlor every day. And bone structure has a lot to do with it too.
You are one of a vast army of silly women. Capital "S," capital "W."

[to Fanny, when she reprimands him for being unfaithful]
You mustn't be too harsh on my secretaries. They were always very understanding when I came to the office after a hard day at home.
Do you think all those years he's been sitting at home waiting for you?
Well, he's always home when I get there.
He's just got a faster car than you.
[first lines]
Good evening, Soames!
Good evening, Mr. Conderley.
Afraid I'm a little early, aren't I?
Miss Trellis wasn't expecting anyone till 8 o'clock.
Well, I thought I'd come a little ahead of time; have a little chat with Miss Fanny.
Sorry, sir; she's still dressing.
All right, I'll wait.
[last lines]
Manby, would you call Janie Clarkson and tell her I can't possibly see her for lunch today?

[laughing]
Yes, Mrs. Skeffington.

[interrupting Mr. Skeffington]
Oh, now I'm about to be challenged. He's gonna throw his cheque book in my face!

[moments later]
If Skeffington's a gentleman, then a swine is what I want to be.
I find one should never look for admirers while at the same time one is falling to bits.

I'm sorry to have to have to be so blunt with you, Mrs. Skeffington, but you're one of a vast army of silly women. Capital "S". Capital "W". You're over dressed, you're over made-up and you're most certainly over perfumed.
Dr. Byles, you are the rudest man I have ever met.
Did you come here to consult a gentlemen or a doctor?
I strongly suspect that you are neither!
Haven't you been reading the paper?
Of course! I never seem to get around to reading the front page though.
If you eat some more daddy, I'll eat some more.
When a man becomes repetitious it's time to go to the district attorney.
I wanted to keep on crying but I didn't have the strength.
Why don't you show uncle George your doll house?
Uncle George, do you want to see my doll's house?
I have to!
I could wring Trippy's neck!
It wouldn't do any good, Georgie. When he was a little boy, we use to put him to bed regularly without any supper, and even then he'd gain weight.
